titles: Die Mercurii 9. Maii, 1660. Upon report this day made to the House from the Committee of Priviledges, it is ordered by the Lords in Parliament assembled, that according to the ancient and undoubted rights of peeridge, no Lord of Parliament, or peer of this realm be or shall be charged, or set at any arms whatsoever, ...
author: England and Wales. Parliament. House of Lords.
publisher: Printed by John Macock, and Francis Tyton, Printers to the House of Lords,
notes: Title from caption and opening lines of text.
"No peer can be charged or set at arms, on any act for trained bands, militia, &c. Their assistants and the attendants of the house are exempt." -- Cf. Steele.
Order to print dated: Die Mercurii 9. Maii, 1660. Signed: Jo. Browne, Cleric. Parliamentorum.
Reproduction of the original in the British Library.
